He was doing business with sex offenders the same way a convenience store or Amazon seller does business with them.

The way it's phrased makes it seem like he was the indirectly benefiting from their crimes, but there was no evidence of this, it's just a throwaway claim they make to malign the guy.

talk.utter: See my followup, I don't think he should have been convicted based on this alone.

talk.author: did:plc:zw3sjffdbuofdlphdwrexuyw
talk.utter: Obscenity is explicitly not protected by the first amendment. This has been established for a while. It could be changed, but I suspect most of the US electorate are okay with obscenity laws as it is and think justice was served in this instance.
